wp:tag.wp:tag_name: he was a bear all along

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: brodiechampion
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my blog. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: An exciting oval shape

item.content:encoded:
Egg person? Egg Person??!! 
Are you trying to give me nightmares?

item.title: Gros Morne Justice: Part 1
item.dc:creator: spikes
item.content:encoded:
Have you ever read a book with plot turns so swift and surprising that you needed to put the book down multiple times to catch your breath? That was our experience just reading the back cover of Gros Morne Justice: A Bear Romantic Comedy Buddy Cop Political Intrigue Survival Thriller. Take a look:   We found this gem at a yard sale on our way back from a camping trip on the Fundy coast of New Brunswick. After reading the back cover of the book, we put it down, walked away from the yard sale and went to eat dinner before starting the drive home to Halifax. But we could not get this book out of our minds. Over dinner we sketched out a plot summary based on our recollection of the back cover text. This is what we got.
  • Jack Crandall and son (Calvin) run an outfitting business and take some wealthy Americans hunting. One of the Americans shoots a bear cub. This illegal kill leads to Jack’s outfitting operation getting shut down.
  • The momma bear begins to plot revenge
  • Bear attacks in Gros Morne begin to increase rapidly.
  • The momma bear kills Calvin, and now Jack has now lost everything!
  • Jack goes off grid, and befriends a Bear, Starlight. Jack begins to see Starlight as a son, and Starlight begins to see Jack as a cub. Unbeknownst to Jack, this is the bear who killed his son.
  • During their time together, Jack and Starlight become able to communicate, and Jack learns that Starlight killed his son. *Awkward!* There is a falling out and eventual reconciliation.
  • An extremist (anti-human) faction of the bear community, responsible for the attacks in Gros Morne, held Starlight in high regard, but see her as a traitor now that she is a friend of Jack.
  • The people in the community blame Starlight for all of the killings in Gros Morne, shun Jack for befriending her, and now Jack and Starlight are on the run together.
  • While lying low Jack and Starlight must uncover the true culprits to clear their names.
  • Final plot twist reveals that the extremist bear faction is lead by Starlight’s presumed-dead cub, aided by Calvin
  • Calvin was a bear all along
We went back and bought the book.
item.category: he was a bear all along

item.title: Gros Morne Justice: Chapter 6
item.dc:creator: spikes
item.content:encoded:
A line from which there can be no return The media is abuzz with bear attack news. One victim of the bear attacks was “Jessie Black of Deer Lake, the reigning queen of the Lomond River Golf Club’s par-three sixth hole.” What. What does that mean. One newspaper reports “BAD-ASSED BEAR NEWS: IT’S BAD, REAL BAD” reporting, “This is the most serious blow to the industry since the 9/11 terrorist attack. Locals have reported cancellations of ten family fishing trips up the Humber River this summer.” The parks officials are trying to hush up and downplay the severity of the bear attacks.   Rick preston along with some other hunters killed seven of the bears. He’s basically a hero. Jack feels defiled by the injustice of this.   Norm hires a new employee for Jack to show around, Mark Hughes. After Jack takes Mark to the cemetery and gets him set up digging some graves, Jack takes off to go feed his bear. The bear suddenly tenses, charges off, and Jack hears a scream. Starlight has pinned Mark Hughes to the ground. Jack says “NO” and the bear releases Mark. Mark explains that Norm had asked him to follow Jack to see where he goes every afternoon. He also helpfully points out that feeding bears isn’t legal. He says that he won’t say anything about what Jack’s been doing, but Jack doesn’t trust him. Jack says “Get him!”, but waffles on his decision and says “No” once Starlight begins attacking again. Starlight does not stop until Mark is dead.   Jack returns Mark to the cemetery, and parades Starlight around, so it will look as if Mark was killed in a bear attack at the cemetery. Jack notes to himself, that maybe he is crossing a line of no return.   Assorted thoughts
  • From the beginning of the chapter “Jack studied the accompanying photo. Yes, Kim Hollings, that was her name. She was trim, black-haired, pretty, with a rosy robust face. She wore her ranger uniform and hat, the epitome of efficiency and detachment. He wondered if she was married.” I don’t really know what to say about that paragraph, but I think Robbie sums it up best with his response of “This is a really nice book.”
  • We finally got a hint of the 9/11 connection that we’ve been waiting for since the celebrity review.
  • I had initially assumed, just based on every single indication of what kind of book this is, that Jack was going to be the archetypical rugged hero-protagonist. But he basically just murdered some kid in order to cover his tracks...the tracks where his habit of feeding human flesh to bears has coincided with a drastic increase in bear attacks on humans. Jack is a full on anti-hero at best. This is a very gritty and sophisticated story!
  • “As he put his plan into motion, somewhere in the back of his mind he registered a detached awareness that he had crossed a line from which there can be no return.” This, in response to commanding your attack bear to attack and kill someone and choosing to try to cover up the death.
  • How does Jack get Starlight to the cemetery? Does he just drive a bear around town in his truck??? The book offers no explanation.
  • This chapter, a montage of bear killings as reported in the newspapers, was called “Marking Territory”. The next chapter is called “When Bears Attack”. Just how much is this going to ramp up?
  Updated Plot Predictions
  • Norm and Jack are now explicitly enemies, since Norm sent Mark to spy on Jack. What were Norm’s suspicions?
  • Jack has successfully trained his bear to attack people, but can’t make the bear stop attacking on command. It seems that Jack’s army is a powerful, but unpredictable, weapon. Is this novel a metaphor for Mutually Assured Destruction?
    • I accidentally typed “meataphor” instead of “metaphor” at first
  • Will Dorothy be eaten by a bear? Will Jack allow, or maybe even command this? “Get her”. I feel like this is the farthest that Jack can fall, but this book always seems to defy our imaginations.

item.title: Gros Morne Justice: Chapter 11
item.dc:creator: spikes
item.content:encoded:
Chapter 11   They’re the most wild. The most alive when they’re wild, the most alive when they’re free, and no bear’s gonna be cooped up for long, you better believe that.   Dorothy and Jack’s marriage continues to disintegrate. Dorothy sees Starlight hanging out on the veranda, and exclaims “Jack! The bear is on the veranda”. Jack, who was dozing in front of the six o’clock news, like a parody of a man utterly disillusioned of life, wakes to Dorothy’s distress thinking “Oh boy, what now?” I mean. It’s just a bear on the verandah. Having his morning coffee, I guess. Why you gotta nag him so much, DOROTHY?   Dorothy is getting used to having Starlight around. “The bear still made her uneasy, but she didn’t have the strength to argue with Jack”   Jack starts spending nights at the funeral home because “the bodies are piling up”. Jack has a plan to save Gros Morne from the bear epidemic: Human meatballs! Jack brings a bunch of garlic and pepper to grind together with bodies from the morgue. He also adds some fancy plant that’ll make the bears real sick. Jack baits some sites with the meatballs.   Assorted thoughts
  • “Jack finds Starlight as fast growing and as inquisitive as Calvin had been.” --in case we hadn’t noticed that Starlight is a surrogate son to Jack.
  Updated plot predictions:
  • Gotta hand it to this book. Human meatballs--we did not see that coming. Are we just going to end up with obnoxious foodie bears insisting on their human flesh being artisanally seasoned?

item.title: Gros Morne Justice: Chapter 13
item.dc:creator: spikes
item.content:encoded:
This “crazy” who you’re talking about is a genius. A real genius.   Dave and Kim piece together that the fancy human meatballs are being used to deter the bears from eating people. They take a team to go tranquilize a bear and bring it back to the lab. In their TRUCK, obviously because that’s just what you do when you want to get a bear from point A to point B, you just put it in the backseat of your car. This is the THIRD instance in this book of people driving around town with a goddamn bear in their car. The first time it happened, we assumed it was a plot hole (clever us: hey author, how did Jack get Starlight from the woods to the funeral home, huh?), but no. NO. The author didn’t bother to mention that Jack took Starlight in his truck because of COURSE he did. That’s just what you DO. Put a bear in your car. We shouldn’t need this spelled out for us. Anyways, there is a marginally tense scene in which the car stalls out and the bear starts waking up, but they all make it back to the lab in one piece.   Assorted Thoughts:
  • When searching for “bears in cars”, google helpfully suggests “bears in cars yosemite”

item.title: Gros Morne Justice: Part 2 (Celebrity review)
item.dc:creator: spikes
item.content:encoded:
The plot thickens before we even begin the story itself. The very first page of the book, a review by Ed Asner, actor, hints at the dark secrets within. “What a provocative idea! I found the novel fascinating … an intriguing story. It bears (no pun intended) not only further reading, but further investigation. A cautionary note: Don’t have anyone read this book to President George Bush and Homeland Security. It might give them terrible ideas.” What terrible ideas could this book have given to the former US president?
    • Bears are sentient, and vengeful. This might lead Homeland Security to eradicate bears as a potential threat to humanity.
    • Bears are terrorists. Canada is harbouring bear terrorists. This book could ignite a war between two long-standing allies.
    • Bears have secret agents among humans. This might start a witch hunt of sorts as Homeland security tries to root out the “bear next door”
    • Newfoundland is a great place for sport hunting and GWB should visit
It seems that this book contains a provocative idea which bears further investigation, but should not fall into the wrong hands. What knowledge could this book bestow upon its readers? And who are we to seek it?

item.title: Gros Morne Justice: Part 2 (UPDATE)
item.dc:creator: spikes
item.content:encoded:
We did some digging to find out more about Ed Asner, of the mysterious celebrity review.  
  • ED ASNER IS A 911 TRUTHER 
  • what does it mean
  • terrorism doesn’t rhyme with bearorism for no reason
  • What is the connection between bears and 911? This is the central question here.

item.title: Gros Morne Justice: Chapter 1
item.dc:creator: spikes
item.content:encoded:
Plot Summary Chapter 1 opens with a picturesque description of the Crandall residence. We meet our hero Jack, his wife Dorothy, and their son Calvin, who currently works at a funeral home, in addition to helping out with his father’s outfitting business. The wealthy Americans arrive, and after one day of hunting, all but one of the hunters has killed a bear. Rick, the leader of the American group, is completely soured by not having bagged a bear. He blames Calvin’s choice of location, and drinks his frustrations away. On the final day of the hunt (not drunk, scout’s honour!), Rick finally gets a kill, and the Americans depart. We get a brief backstory interlude on Jack, where we learn that his stepfather used to beat him. When Calvin is late returning from a baiting expedition, Jack seeks him out in the woods, only to find that Calvin has been mauled to death by a bear. When the bear becomes aggressive - smashing in part of the windshield of Jack’s truck, Jack leaves the scene to get reinforcements in town, and returns to kill the bear. Jack finds a dead bear cub nearby, and concludes that it was killed by Rick, enraging the momma bear who then killed Calvin. Assorted thoughts
    • “They don’t understand bears, Dorothy.”
    • Calvin is way too into funeral homes
      • Calvin “jokingly suggests” feeding dead people to the bears????? This has to be a plot point later in the book. Did Calvin give the bears a taste for human flesh?
      • Note that increasing bear aggression levels in this way will only lead to more business.
    • Norm Cotton, the funeral home director who Calvin works for, “already owned a Mercedes, a Ford Explorer, a BMW, a fifty foot sailboat, and a house and condo in St. John’s,” and was even talking about “buying his own Lear jet.” Why is running a funeral home such a lucrative business in Deer Lake? WHY CAN A FUNERAL HOME DIRECTOR AFFORD A PRIVATE JET? Does this ever happen in real life?
      • The average salary for a funeral director in Canada is $43,000. Something is UP with this funeral home
      • A quick google search shows that Lear jets cost between 20 and 70 million dollars. How rich would you have to be before you would spend tens of millions of dollars on what is essentially a toy? Hey everyone, let’s think about what our most expensive toy costs! [Jess says: my most expensive toy is my piano which cost thousands of dollars, which is an order of magnitude less than my prospective salary]. So let’s say that whimsical purchases stay at least an order of magnitude below annual salary. This would put Norm Cotton’s annual salary in the hundreds of millions of dollars range. No matter how many bears are bribing Norm for that sweet sweet human flesh, there is no way this makes sense. This book has to be going deep into conspiracy territory.
      • Google’s ballpark average North American funeral costs is somewhere near $7,000. The population of Newfoundland is roughly 530,000, and has a mortality rate of about 6.7 per 1000 (as of 2007) Though, this appears to be on the decline, so let’s say 0.007. Assuming that Norm is the only funeral director in all of Newfoundland, his average salary would be around $26,000,000. But we feel like his annual income should be a full order of magnitude larger! How many people are these bears killing?! (33,000 per year!)
      • The bear population in Newfoundland and Labrador is estimated to be between 6,000 and 10,000 bears. Hence, each bear on average would be responsible for about 3 to 6 deaths per year. Given the crazy aggressiveness of bears in this universe, that doesn’t actually sound too high.
    • We spend a lot of time in Dorothy’s head at the beginning of this chapter. Is she the stealth protagonist of this novel? Hahaha no, apparently all she thinks about is the men in her life. How hard is this book going to fail the Bechdel test? Is she a bear? Not completely ruling it out.
      • The cub (presumably “Starlight”), will become Jack’s companion. What gender are they? Starlight, filling the void left by Calvin’s death, is like a surrogate son to Jack. Is Starlight a lady bear? Will Starlight having amazing heart to hearts with Dorothy?
      • Is there a Bearchdel test we can consider as well?
     
  • Apparently black bears in Newfoundland are super aggressive and “more carnivorous”! This seems to just be a feature of the Gros Morne Justice universe, as black bears are typically very timid and tend to avoid human contact. The prologue to this book consists of two pages of (seemingly factual) geographical and sociological background information on Newfoundland, with this paragraph in the middle:
    • “Not long ago the bears in and around the great national park Gros Morne and the town of Deer Lake turned against the residents for reasons that are still mostly a matter of speculation, but no doubt these reasons are closely associated with man’s folly.” (feeding human flesh to bears?)
    • There are 0 google search results for “bear attacks” + “deer river” + newfoundland before 2004 (the publication date of this book). So it seems that the strange behaviour of Newfoundland black bears is a feature of this particular fiction...or part of a massive government cover-up.
    • According to a most helpful wikipedia page, there were 16 fatal black bear attacks (and 11 fatal brown bear attacks) in North America in the entire decade of 2000-2009.
  • We are becoming increasingly suspicious of most characters, and how they may secretly be bears. The only characters in the book who have mostly slipped under our radar so far are in fact the “bears”.
  • Who was the cub’s father? Was it Calvin?
Updated plot predictions
  • Norm Cotton has definitely been feeding dead people to the bears, and they have become more aggressive due to acquiring a taste for human flesh.
    • In addition to Calvin’s “jokes” about feeding corpses to bears to reduce the costs of funerals, Chapter 1 also presents this odd exchange:
      • “Bears have finicky tastes. They don’t like garlic and pepper in their meat”. Jack explained to them that he had once tried sausage on bears and found that it never worked at bait sites. “You should rub yourselves with garlic and pepper,” he said, “If a bear starts to bite you, it will be turned off by the seasoning, I assure you.”
  • Since the momma bear who killed Calvin is dead by the close of Chapter 1, it seems that Starlight is, not Calvin’s killer, but another cub of Calvin’s killer. This will be even more emotionally resonant, since Jack will become Starlight’s missing parent, as Starlight becomes Jack’s missing son. There will be an awkward falling out between Starlight and Jack will when Starlight finds out that it was Jack who killed Starlight’s mother.
  • For a few minutes, after Jack left Calvin’s body in the woods, it seemed like our predictions about Calvin (i.e., miraculously still alive and leader of the radical anti-human bear faction) were going to come true. *Unfortunately,* Calvin’s body is recovered.

item.title: Gros Morne Justice: Chapter 2
item.dc:creator: spikes
item.content:encoded:
Plot Summary In Chapter 2, Jack receives word that he is to be held responsible for Rick’s illegal killing of the bear cub. This puts his business at risk, and puts him in a precarious financial position. He also has funeral costs for Calvin to consider. He discusses funeral arrangements with Norm, who pushes for cremation. He also offers to perform Calvin’s ceremony for free, and offers Jack a job at the funeral home. Partway through Chapter 2, we switch over to Norm Cotten’s point of view, which opens on this ominous paragraph: “The next day, in a cemetery in Deer Lake, Norm, dressed in blue jeans and a work shirt, was digging a grave. He laughed to himself every so often as he dug away. His laughter had the ring of vindication, the laughter of a supreme ironist, or a successful criminal, the secret laugh of a man who enjoyed winning at all costs.” Norm then fields a call from his black market human organ dealer. Assorted thoughts
  • ALL OF OUR SUSPICIONS HAVE BEEN CONFIRMED
  • AND YET WORSE
  • GOOD GOD
  • We learn a lot about Norm’s business model:
    • Some morgues in Cape Breton don’t have the space to store all of their corpses, so funeral homes as far away as Newfoundland can step in and pick up the slack! This provides an additional source of revenue for Norm
    • Norm makes all his money trafficking human organs
    • Norm fakes cremations, and sells the organs of the deceased on the black market.
    • $25,000 / set of organs, is roughly his rate.
    • Organs are sold for science or “other nefarious purposes”.  WHAT?
    • Norm weaseled his way into taking over the funeral home business after the previous owner died, after a fairly mysterious career trajectory
 
    • We were not kidding about the funeral home giving the bears a taste for human flesh!
      • Norm sometimes disposes of body parts in the woods when his organ broker shows up late for a pickup
      • Norm discussing Calvin’s body
        • “...there was too little for cremation. I tossed his torso myself...I am sure he made a good meal for the bears”
        • Norm has indeed been feeding human remains to bears
   
  • Apparently Calvin was a little too interested in how “the business” worked. Norm was glad to see him go.
  • Norm contemplates how after just a few years in this business, he’ll be able to retire very comfortably!
    • While reading Chapter 1, we were discussing why anyone would want to buy a private jet instead of just...not working anymore. Seems like this Norm fellow had the same idea! Norm Cotten, what a relatable character!
    • Maybe he just wanted a private jet to make it easier for him to make deliveries to his black market contacts?
Updated Predictions
  • We are now 100% certain that the bears have become aggressive because they have acquired a taste for human flesh due to Norm’s shady burial practices.
  • The book will reveal that Norm arranged for Calvin to die in order to keep Norm’s illegal dealings secret
  • Jack is going to start piecing everything together over the course of the book!
  • Eventually, Dorothy learns that Norm is responsible for Calvin’s death, and kills him, like the mother bear enraged by the loss of her cub.

item.title: Gros Morne Justice: Chapter 3
item.dc:creator: brodiechampion
item.content:encoded:
Plot Sumarry Chapter 3 basically deals with the court case against Jack, who is being held liable for Rick’s illegal killing of the bear cub. Jack hires a lawyer and has his day in court, but ultimately, the judge rules against him, stripping him of his outfitters license. Assorted thoughts
  • This chapter doesn’t have anything too crazy in it--it’s just there to move the plot along to where Jack is no longer an outfitter.
  • However, we do get this progressive gem: She must know her stuff, Jack thought, and she might be just the ticket for the prosecutors in Corner Brook. “I don’t have any problem with a woman as my attorney,” he said aloud. (To no one in particular.) Thanks for clearing that up, Jack!
Updated plot predictions
  • Nothing notable happened in this chapter that wasn’t outlined in the back cover summary, so all our current plot predictions will stay in place.

item.title: Gros Morne Justice: Chapter 4
item.dc:creator: spikes
item.content:encoded:
Don't feed the bears (human flesh). Plot Summary Dorothy “Plot Point” Crandall has a stroke and is partially paralyzed. To pay for Dorothy’s medical care, Jack and Dorothy sell the lodge and Jack gets a job full time at the funeral home. One day, out and about in town, Jack is enraged to see Rick Preston back in town with another outfitter. Jack has to pick up a corpse at the county morgue and bring back to the funeral home to cremate. On his way back, he goes for a drive to calm himself down. He stops at the place in the park where Calvin was killed. Jack notices a pair of bear cubs, and does what any man worth his weight would do, and pulls the corpse out the back and feeds it to the bears. “Jack wondered just how dangerous it was to feed human flesh to the cubs. Idly, he considered how naturally the idea had occurred to him. But a question was still unanswered. Would feeding bears human flesh condition them to wanting only human flesh?” Jack gets in the habit of feeding the bears meat and donuts. Feeding the bears is therapeutic. Jack realized that cremains can easily be swapped out with dirt, should his bear friends get a hankering. Assorted thoughts
  • This book has really embraced the idea of feeding people to bears. Honestly, we really try to make up the most absurd outcomes for this book, but it is one step ahead of us the whole way. Bears eating people appears to be a major theme!
  • We already knew that Norm occasionally feeds corpses to the bears. Calvin also had inclinations about doing so, and now Jack has leapt into the deep end as well. Perhaps everyone feeds people to bears - it simply isn’t proper to speak of it. It’s everyone’s cheeky little secret.
  • Why does everyone involved with the funeral home want to feed people to bears? If it’s not everyone in town, it’s surely everyone connected with Norm. What is going on? Is Norm a bear? Is Norm working for the bears?
Updated plot predictions
  • Jack is definitely going to lead his army of man-eating bears against his nemesis, Rick Preston.
  • Jack and Norm will have a power struggle for control of the man-eating bear army. One man will end up as bear food. One man will end up as king.
item.category: he was a bear all along

item.title: Gros Morne Justice: Chapter 5
item.dc:creator: spikes
item.content:encoded:
Plot summary Jack keeps feeding the bears and is training them to respond to commands. ~*Winter passes*~ In the spring, the male bear has come out of hibernation, but Jack finds the lady bear dead from a vicious attack. Jack and Norm are becoming annoyed with one another. Assorted thoughts
  • Jack likes taking care of the orphaned bears because “it was nice to be needed”. Ummm...paralyzed wife might need you a bit, dude?
  • Bears have clearly defined gender roles!
  • Beat your kids! Beat your bears! It’s the only way for them to learn.
  • Jack still has occasional fits of rage
Updated Plot Predictions
  • All signs still point to Jack leading a man-eating bear army, and a showdown between Jack and Norm!

item.title: Gros Morne Justice: Chapter 6
item.dc:creator: spikes
item.content:encoded:
A line from which there can be no return Plot Summary The local media is abuzz with news of the bear attacks. One victim of the bear attacks was “Jessie Black of Deer Lake, the reigning queen of the Lomond River Golf Club’s par-three sixth hole.” What. What does that mean. The Northern Examiner gives it to us straight: “BAD-ASSED BEAR NEWS: IT’S BAD, REAL BAD” reporting, “This is the most serious blow to the industry since the 9/11 terrorist attack. Locals have reported cancellations of ten family fishing trips up the Humber River this summer.” The parks officials are trying to hush up and downplay the severity of the bear attacks. Rick preston along with some other hunters killed seven of the bears. He’s basically a hero. Jack feels defiled by the injustice of this. Norm hires a new employee for Jack to show around, Mark Hughes. After Jack takes Mark to the cemetery and gets him set up digging some graves, Jack takes off to go feed his bear. The bear suddenly tenses, charges off, and Jack hears a scream. Starlight has pinned Mark Hughes to the ground. Jack says “NO” and the bear releases Mark. Mark explains that Norm had asked him to follow Jack to see where he goes every afternoon. He also helpfully points out that feeding bears isn’t legal. He says that he won’t say anything about what Jack’s been doing, but Jack doesn’t trust him. Jack says “Get him!”, but waffles on his decision and says “No” once Starlight begins attacking again. Starlight does not stop until Mark is dead. Jack returns Mark to the cemetery, and parades Starlight around, so it will look as if Mark was killed in a bear attack at the cemetery. Jack notes to himself, that maybe he is crossing a line of no return. Assorted thoughts
  • From the beginning of the chapter “Jack studied the accompanying photo. Yes, Kim Hollings, that was her name. She was trim, black-haired, pretty, with a rosy robust face. She wore her ranger uniform and hat, the epitome of efficiency and detachment. He wondered if she was married.” I don’t really know what to say about that paragraph, but I think Robbie sums it up best with his response of “This is a really nice book.”
  • We finally got a hint of the 9/11 connection that we’ve been waiting for since the celebrity review.
  • I had initially assumed, just based on every single indication of what kind of book this is, that Jack was going to be the archetypical rugged hero-protagonist. But he basically just murdered some kid in order to cover his tracks...the tracks where his habit of feeding human flesh to bears has coincided with a drastic increase in bear attacks on humans. Jack is a full on anti-hero at best. This is a very gritty and sophisticated story!
  • “As he put his plan into motion, somewhere in the back of his mind he registered a detached awareness that he had crossed a line from which there can be no return.” This, in response to commanding your attack bear to attack and kill someone and choosing to try to cover up the death.
  • How does Jack get Starlight to the cemetery? Does he just drive a bear around town in his truck??? The book offers no explanation.
  • This chapter, a montage of bear killings as reported in the newspapers, was called “Marking Territory”. The next chapter is called “When Bears Attack”. Just how much is this going to ramp up?
Updated Plot Predictions
  • Norm and Jack are now explicitly enemies, since Norm sent Mark to spy on Jack. What were Norm’s suspicions?
  • Jack has successfully trained his bear to attack people, but can’t make the bear stop attacking on command. It seems that Jack’s army is a powerful, but unpredictable, weapon. Is this novel a metaphor for Mutually Assured Destruction?
    • I accidentally typed “meataphor” instead of “metaphor” at first
  • Will Dorothy be eaten by a bear? Will Jack allow, or maybe even command this? “Get her”. I feel like this is the farthest that Jack can fall, but this book always seems to defy our imaginations.

item.title: Gros Morne Justice: Chapter 7
item.dc:creator: spikes
item.content:encoded:
Theirs was a friendship forged from the intensity of a daring and dangerous encounter Chapter 7 introduces us to our new hero, Dave Bishop, Ph.D, who works for the National Parks and Wildlife Department. We get to know Dave pretty well this chapter, as we hear all about his “trim, youthful physique and professorial manner,” “rugged disposition” and how “his face reflected an intense mental alertness and a focused gaze. He was all business, ready, decisive; there wasn’t much about him that went unnoticed.” He also has a bunch of cool scars and stuff <3 Dave travels from Ottawa to Gros Morne to help out with the bear situation, which puts him in the path of the lovely Kim Hollings, park ranger, whom Dave likes, but doesn’t like like. However, her profile “reminded Dave of many Greco-Roman paintings and statues,” and he was pleased when she changed into “tight dirty jeans that accentuated her long legs and gave her curves in all the right places.” They spend a romantic evening collecting scat samples and measuring a trapped and tranquilized bear’s penis together. <3 The book takes a sharp detour into some low-key bear erotica: ‘Meanwhile Kim gripped a pair of calipers and carefully measured the animal’s testicles and penis. The organ was erect and thrust well forward beyond its foreskin sheath. “Let’s hope he’s a sound sleeper” Dave quipped.” On the way out of the forest they are attacked by a bear. Dave saves Kim. Dave offers to hang around with Kim for awhile after the attack, but was worried that she might “get the wrong impression.” It happens to Dave the Rugged Ladykiller a lot. Updated Plot Predictions
  • Now that we have a plausible hero/protagonist in Dave, it seems even more likely that Jack will end up being a straight villain rather than an anti-hero. This is reassuring! Jack is pretty unhinged already!

item.title: Gros Morne Justice: Chapter 8
item.dc:creator: spikes
item.content:encoded:
The bear is dirty. The bear is why you can’t keep clean. Plot Summary While analysing some of the bear scat that they had retrieved, Dave and his lab friends find human flesh in some of the samples. This is puzzling however, since the samples did not come from locations where people have been reported missing. Recognizing the urgency of the situation, Dave suggests placing a bounty on bears for hunters, and the government was quick to approve this. He was really making quite the name for himself. “The good press made his personal stock soar in the public eye. The Northern Examiner reported that he was the hero of the bear attack suffered by Kim and himself, not the other way around. Life was never fair, he admitted guiltily to himself, but what could he do? Write a correction to the paper?” Jack, while out salmon fishing, ran into his bear. Because of the new bounty, he decided that Starlight might not be safe. Jack lures his bear into his truck, drives him home, and tethers him to a post behind his shed.  Dorothy is very concerned. Jack says it’s no big deal, and gives her the fish that he had caught. I am THRILLED that I have another excuse to use the “driving in cars with bears” tag. Dave and Kim are tipped off that four bears are headed for a campground full of boy scouts. Thankfully, the boy scouts had all their food properly hung up in bear bags, so the bears just trashed the place and left. All the boy scouts were okay. Dorothy expresses a little bit more concern over Starlight, but Jack just says “It’s fine.” Jack then notices the front page of The Northern Examiner. Rick Preston is now a local hero. He had just killed his fifth bear for the parks department. Assorted thoughts
  • How many bears are eating people at this point?
  • Who falls for who? Dave, Kim, Rick, Jack, Starlight, Norm, etc. etc.
  • What is Norm Cotten up to these days?
Updated plot predictions
  • Jack’ allows Starlight to kill Dorothy. That was supposed to be a maximally ridiculous prediction, but now I think this definitely happens. Jack clearly has exactly zero fucks to give about what Dorothy thinks:
    • Dorothy sees that Jack has a bear and asks him “was that a bear?” Jack replies with “Yep. I’m taming it. It’s no problem”. Dorothy is (understandably) upset, saying “A bear, lmagine! We have a bear. Oh my. They’re attacking people and he wants to bring one home. Oh my nerves.” Without a word, Jack goes back to the truck and holds up a salmon. This is enough to distract Dorothy from the issue of Jack bringing a wild bear onto their property during peak bearpocalypse. Is Dorothy simple, or is she terrified of Jack and is afraid to press the (totally legitimate!) issue?
    • Later when Dorothy gets upset about the bear again, Jack shuts her down with “You mustn't get excited. You don’t want a relapse.” Dorothy replies “Sometime I can’t help but get upset, I was hoping you’d get rid of that bear.” All Jack has to say in response is “He’s fine,” and Dorothy immediately drops the issue again.
    • If Dorothy ever develops any backbone whatsoever, she is going to become a barrier between Jack and Starlight. Who do you think Jack will side with?
  • Nearly everything we predict, no matter how insane and far fetched it seems to us, this book delivers. How can we make a prediction that is too insane for this book? This is Brodie’s best attempt today: After Starlight kills Dorothy, Jack helps Starlight eat Dorothy. Jack thinks that he actually is a bear.
  • Jack stalks and kills Rick Preston in a bear like manner.

item.title: Gros Morne Justice: Chapters 9 and 10
item.dc:creator: spikes
item.content:encoded:
But who? How? This is such a small place and everyone knows everyone else. How could they get away with it? Plot Summary More bear attacks! Two boys are attacked and the parents of the boys sue the province for gross negligence. The Northern Examiner releases another on-point headline: “Grossed out at Gros Morne national park bear lunch.” A town meeting is held with everyone being angry at the park and government officials. Why won’t someone do something? A letter from Richard “Rich” Richards of Concord, New Hampshire is read, talking about his awful trip to the park. “This Yank ain’t coming back” Kim and Dave are looking for bears. A shot bear runs off into the woods. They follow it and Kim finishes it off. Based on scat samples, Dave concludes that the bears are eating human flesh without any bones, implying that someone must be feeding them. Kim points out that abortions are up this year, so perhaps the bears have been chowing down on all the fetuses. Dave and Kim go hunting with Rick Preston and his buddies. Rick kills a moose by accident. Assorted Thoughts
  • Presumably Jack is the only person regularly feeding bears nice butchered meat at this point, and Norm is the only one regularly feeding human remains to bears. But then, how are bears eating human flesh without bone? Does that mean Norm is removing the bones, feeding the bears, and then just cremating whatever is left over? That seems like a lot of work.
  • "There were outbursts of hysteria from the women while the men voiced anger and frustration."
    • silly women getting all emotional when they should be getting angry or frustrated

item.title: Gros Morne Justice: Chapter 11
item.dc:creator: spikes
item.content:encoded:
They’re the most wild. The most alive when they’re wild, the most alive when they’re free, and no bear’s gonna be cooped up for long, you better believe that. Plot Summary Dorothy and Jack’s marriage continues to disintegrate. Dorothy sees Starlight hanging out on the veranda, and exclaims “Jack! The bear is on the veranda”. Jack, who was dozing in front of the six o’clock news, like a parody of a man utterly disillusioned of life, wakes to Dorothy’s distress thinking “Oh boy, what now?” I mean. It’s just a bear on the verandah. Having his morning coffee, I guess. Why you gotta nag him so much, DOROTHY? Dorothy is getting used to having Starlight around. “The bear still made her uneasy, but she didn’t have the strength to argue with Jack” Jack starts spending nights at the funeral home because “the bodies are piling up”. Jack has a plan to save Gros Morne from the bear epidemic: Human meatballs! Jack brings a bunch of garlic and pepper to grind together with bodies from the morgue. He also adds some fancy plant that’ll make the bears real sick. Jack baits some sites with the meatballs. Assorted thoughts
  • “Jack finds Starlight as fast growing and as inquisitive as Calvin had been.” --in case we hadn’t noticed that Starlight is a surrogate son to Jack.
Updated plot predictions
  • Gotta hand it to this book. Human meatballs--we did not see that coming. Are we just going to end up with obnoxious foodie bears insisting on their human flesh being artisanally seasoned?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: cialis purchasing http://vioglichfu.7m.pl/ You've made the point.

item.title: Gros Morne Justice: Chapter 12
item.dc:creator: spikes
item.content:encoded:
The bear was his only friend now. Plot Summary Chapter 12 opens with Norm Cotten’s suggestion that Jack take some time off to be with his wife. This makes Jack furious, naturally. While Jack is away on unspecified business, Starlight breaks into the house and kills Dorothy. Jack approves. A bear’s gotta do what a bear’s gotta do. Jack cries, but “not the tears of grief, but of the same old hatred and rage.” No grief for poor ol’ Dorothy. While there was no way for Jack to cover up that a bear had attacked Dorothy, he makes sure to give the park officials an incorrect description of Starlight in the hopes of protecting the bear. Jack doesn’t blame Starlight. The bear is all he has left. No, Starlight was just doing what he was conditioned to do. Jack is in the woods near his house with Starlight, when he stumbles across Rick out hunting for the bear that killed Dorothy. Rick offers Jack his shotgun, saying that Jack should have the chance to take out his wife’s killer. While Jack is holding Rick’s shotgun, Starlight sneaks up behind Rick and kills him. Jack approves. Since Jack blames Rick for everything bad that has happened to him, including Dorothy’s death, Jack feels like justice has been served (Gros Morne justice, perhaps). The park rangers have caught a bear which recently ate one of Jack’s meatballs, and hadn’t finished digesting it yet.  The meatball - perhaps more of a jumbo sausage, still had the sausage wrapping. Assorted Thoughts
  • What was Jack doing when he left Dorothy home alone? Was he laying out his human meat balls?
  • The chapter didn’t end when Dorothy died. The chapter didn’t end when Rick died. Dave finds one clue, and we need to end the chapter immediately. Clearly Dave is the protagonist of this story.
    • I’m left wondering what is left to happen to Jack. His storyline seems to have wrapped up. What is Jack’s big choice, as promised by the back of the book?
  • “Jack felt Norm was unreasonable by insisting that he take a week off work” after his wife’s death. Jack’s all like, I’m not sad, these are just RAGE TEARS. Lemme get back to work.
  • “Dorothy wouldn’t want to be a burden on you, Jack.” Dorothy’s sister understands Jack and Dorothy’s relationship.
Updated Plot Predictions
  • Jack’s Big Choice is that he’s going to have to choose between killing Starlight and saving the community from more bear attacks. WHAT DOES JACK CHOOSE? Obviously, he saves the puny humans. But WHY? And what is he left with? The bear is his only friend now.

item.title: Dishwashers are overrated
item.dc:creator: spikes
item.content:encoded:
1. Washing a dish takes 10 seconds. Putting a dish in the dishwasher takes 7 seconds. 3 seconds is nothing.
  2. You can keep standing straight up to wash dishes in the sink. You have to bend over to put something in the dishwasher.
  3. Dishes in the dish drying rack are always clean, so you can get into a habit of putting a dish or two away whenever you are waiting for something on the stove.
  4. You don't have to empty the whole dish drying rack at once, but if you only empty part of the dishwasher, you have ruined *everything*.
  5. We only need one cheese grater now, since it is always clean.
  6. No reaching into the gross dirty dishwasher to get a fork to wash because we are always out of goddamn clean forks
  7. There's a dish drying rack on the counter now, so there's a place to put frying pans after we wash them instead of putting them in the cupboard wet. (Hand drying dishes is completely out of the question, no one will ever convince me otherwise.)
  8. Wash your party dishes by hand while you're sobering up. You're hanging out in the kitchen anyways, drunko.
  9. We negotiated $25 off our rent because we don't have a dishwasher, that's like a pizza a month.
  10. You develop a mentality of constant kitchen vigilance. Dishwasher is like a Deus ex Machina, you just let the kitchen go to hell and figure it will get better once the dishwasher gets run. And emptied. And refilled.
